header.h1: Student Work Permits During School Closures

p.b: Students Currently on a Work Permit

p.span: SBUSD students cannot leave home to work unless their employer falls within an essential industry sector, regardless of whether a work permit is new or has already been issued. Non-essential employers should not continue to require students to be physically present in their facilities, and essential employers should ensure proper social distancing and hygiene within their facilities. We encourage families to contact employers to confirm that they are essential, and to ask about social distancing and hygiene procedures. Please see the list of CA approved essential jobs linked in below.

p.b: Students wishing to obtain a Work Permit

p.span: The Santa Barbara Unified School District recognizes that during school closures related to COVID-19, students may need to apply for a Work Permit. School sites are able to issue new Work Permits to students who meet eligibility guidelines.
In addition to the Work Permit Application form (B1-1), students will also be required to have their prospective employers complete an

a.span: Affidavit of Compliance with Shelter In Place Order form

p.span: which can be completed electronically, or submitted at the same time as the Work Permit Application (B1-1). In order for the SBUSD to approve a Work Permit Application, the prospective employer must verify that either they will allow the student to complete all work duties from the student’s home, or, they are exempt from the shelter in place order because they are an essential job and can describe a detailed plan to implement social distancing and health safety measures in the workplace environment.

As the CDE and CA Employment Office continue to require live signatures on all Work Permit documents, the SBUSD strongly cautions students, employees, and families to take all measures of health safety precautions when obtaining the required signatures.

p.b: Process for obtaining a Work Permit. Please go to your school of attendance:

li.span: Students must complete the Work Permit application (also known as B1-1 form) complete with all signatures from their potential employer, and their parents.
Students take a photo of or scan the complete the Work Permit application and email it to the contacts for their school of attendance.

Students have their potential employer complete the Affidavit of Compliance with Shelter in Place form. This can be done with the electronic form or with a paper form. Work Permits will not be issued to students without a copy of this form on file.

Once the Work Permit application is approved and the Affidavit form has been received, the student will be notified that a Work Permit has been issued. A complete permit will be mailed back to the student via the US Postal Service to the address provided on the Work Permit application form.
Students must either keep their original Work Permit application on file to turn into their College and Career Center when school resumes, or, they can mail it to the school directly.

p.strong: Will SBUSD continue to process new work permit requests during the period of school closures?
p.br: Yes. SBUSD will process work permits during the period of school closures.

p.strong: Are there specific criteria that students must meet in order to obtain a work permit?
p.br: Yes. Only students age 12 and older may receive work permits. Students must also maintain a GPA of 2.0 or higher. If a student does not meet the eligibility criteria, the student should connect with their counselor and principal at their school of attendance to consider developing a support plan.

p.strong: Are there limits on the number of hours that students may work while schools are closed?
p.br:
Yes. Although schools are not physically open, school is still in session. This means that the ordinary limits on the number of hours that students may work are still in effect. Unless certain exceptions apply, these limits are:
12-13 years old: May only work on weekends and school holidays. May not work on school days.
14-15 years old: On weekends and school holidays, may work 8 hours per day. On school days, may only work 3 hours per day.
16-17 years old: On weekends, school holidays, and days preceding weekends and school holidays, may work 8 hours per day. On other school days, may only work 4 hours per day.

p.strong: Are there limits on the types of work that students may do, in light of shelter-in-place orders?
p.br:
Yes. Everyone in Santa Barbara County must comply with the shelter-in-place orders issued by Santa Barbara County Public Health Department and Governor Newsom. Per these orders, individuals may only leave their homes in order to carry out “essential” functions (e.g., healthcare, food distribution, law enforcement, etc.).
California’s list of essential functions is available at https://covid19.ca.gov/img/EssentialCriticalInfrastructureWorkers.pdf.
As explained above, SBUSD is requiring employers to complete an Affidavit of Compliance with Shelter-in-Place Orders form, which states that, if the employer is requiring students to leave their homes in order to complete their work duties, it is because the employer is carrying out essential functions. And, the employer can guarantee that social distancing and health safety measures are being implemented in the work environment.

p.strong: Do these limits apply to students with existing work permits?
p.br: Yes. Regardless of whether a work permit is new or has already been issued, SBUSD students cannot leave home to work unless their employer falls within an essential industry sector. Non-essential employers should not continue to require students to be physically present in their facilities, and essential employers should ensure proper social distancing and hygiene within their facilities. We encourage families to contact employers to confirm that they are essential, and to ask about social distancing and hygiene procedures.

p.strong: Will the SBUSD issue Work Permits over the summer?
p.br: Yes. Students are eligible to apply for Work Permits over the summer. Work Permit Applications will be processed at school sites until May 29th. Further guidance about how Work Permit applications will be processed after May 29th will be released in mid-May.

SBUnified requires that school personnel take immediate steps to intervene when safe to do so when he or she witnesses an act of discrimination, harassment, intimidation, or bullying.

The Governing Board prohibits sexual harassment of district employees and students. The Board also prohibits retaliatory behavior or action against any person who reports, files a complaint or testifies about, or otherwise supports a complainant in alleging sexual harassment.
